activity-date.narrative: Activity started in 2016 and lasted for 5 and half years.

organisation.narrative: Environmental Centre for Oil Spills and Gas Flaring (NACGOND)

recipient-country.narrative: Project activities were implemented in parts of Cross River, Akwa Ibom, Abia, Rivers, Bayelsa and Delta States in the South-South region of Nigeria.

sector.narrative: Activities were part of series of programmes designed to strengthen Civil Society space and knowledge of community persons to boast environmental governance lobbying and advocacy to ensure effective laws and policies.

condition.narrative: NACGOND observed over the years that people of the region have been made to feel unduly dependent on the exploration and exploitation of oil and gas resources, which bears very few opportunities for the youths. Many youths across local communities in the region have no independent, productive livelihood sources. This has created a scenario of collective frustration and the oil and gas industry activities have become easy targets for oil theft, pipeline vandalism and artisanal refining activities. This activity was created to orientate the youths (of secondary school age) to values of environmental stewardship, through strategic ecological education, awareness creation, and media education programmes targeted at behavioral change for environmental leadership of the region.

title.narrative: The surge in awareness levels among school club members across targeted communities informed the decision to extend club structures to community level in communities where environmental problems had large impact in the Niger Delta. Environmental Monitoring Clubs (EMCs) were established in selected communities across the Niger Delta with quarterly visits undertaken to ascertain that club members were in line with intended objectives. Media campaigns were done through airing of strategic radio drama series and production of NACGOND information materials. These were seen as necessary to augment other activities that were already being implemented in line with this particular objective.

description.narrative: There was need to reduced number of youths involved in environmental pollution activities in communities where project was implemented. This included activities of third parties that caused pipeline vandalism, oil theft and artisanal refining of crude oil and other related activities that impacted negatively on the environment and livelihood safety.

comment.narrative: New environmental knowledge acquired by 1,260 school age students in 27 schools created opportunity for widespread dissemination of this knowledge among school age youths through peer-to-peer education in schools and in the communities.

target.value: A significant number of youths in communities where project was implemented acquired adequate knowledge of environmental issues affecting them. This was needed to form their minds towards behavioural change for better environmental management.

location.ref: 61 project communities across 6 states of the Niger Delta where project was implemented.

dimension.name: 27 NACGOND school clubs significantly increased their environmental awareness, and became better equipped to undertake individual environmental advocacies, especially those triggered by third party interference in project communities.

90% of school environmental club members acquired tailored environmental education provided by the programme due to buy-in from heads of those schools which has increased their individual campaigns against oil spills and other forms of environmental pollution in their communities.

A total of 1,304 secondary school students acquired tailored environmental education mainstreaming deforestation with enhanced knowledge on environmental leadership outreach activities and also developed capacity to design and implement club action plans to facilitate their work during and after the project lifespan.

About 95% youths in the environmental school clubs have developed enough capacity from implemented programmes, and now individually campaign for better environmental management in project communities. They also engaged in tree planting exercises as an adaptation measure. About 2 law-making institutions at the local government level in one of the project states, out of six, have commenced initiating motions for inclusion of climate change issues in local government budgets.

Environmental school competitions carried out significantly strengthened club leadership base of 1,260 secondary school students across 27 schools, out of 50, in communities over the 6 Niger Delta project states.
dimension.value: 1,260 students in 27 schools across the 6 states of the Niger Delta.

dimension.name: General environmental awareness was extensively created by implementing partners. Specific knowledge on pollution especially caused by third party interference, which would have escalated intended result, was still being required.
dimension.value: Increased need for environmental awareness was required to change the situation.

dimension.name: Increase of 70% environmental school club members’ individual campaigns against third party interference in environmental systems was recorded, with higher result recorded for control of deforestation in project communities.

Surge in youths’ individual campaigns against environmental problems had significant influence from media activities implemented activities targeted at youths through various channels across project states in the Niger Delta.
dimension.value: Increased in the level of awareness among participants.
